part.title: Overview
part.para: The Lunar Extension Framework (lunarx) provides developers with an easy way to extend the basic functionality provided by the Lunar File Manager. The lunarx library includes interfaces that can be implemented by extensions for various purposes.
It is based on the GLib Dynamic Type System and loads the extensions on demand to reduce the system resources allocated for the file manager process.

sect1.title: Goals
sect1.para: The Lunar Extension Framework was developed with the following goals in mind:

orderedlist.listitem: It should be easy to extend the functionality of the file manager in certain ways.
The internals of the file manager should be hidden from the extensions to be able to maintain API/ABI compatibility for extensions over various major releases of the file manager.

Provide basic compatibility with the Nautilus Extension Framework, so vendors don't need to write several versions of their extensions for the various file managers. With the current implementation it should be easy to write a small wrapper library for generic extensions that can be loaded into both Lunar and Nautilus.

Extensions should not be loaded into memory until they are actually required to save system resources. This differs from the way Nautilus handles extensions and therefore people that already know how to write Nautilus extensions must be careful when writing extensions for Lunar, because Lunar actually unloads the extension when it's no longer needed. The GTypePlugin and GTypeModule sections in the GObject Reference Manual provide details about the handling of dynamic type plugins.
Permit developers to write extensions in languages other than C.

part.title: Writing Extensions
part.para: This section explains the basic steps required to write an extension for the Lunar File Manager using the C language interface. It is just a short introduction and not meant to provide extensive details about the internal workings of the file manager.

sect2.title: Extensions and Providers
sect2.para: Lunar Extensions are shared libraries that extend the basic functionality provided by the Lunar File Manager. An extension exports one or more GObjects, called providers, to Lunar.

Providers implement one or more of the GInterfaces included with the lunarx library. The currently exported interfaces include the LunarxMenuProvider for adding context menu items to the file views, the LunarxPropertyPageProvider for adding pages to the file properties dialog, the LunarxPreferencesProvider for adding items to the preferences section of the main menu, and the LunarxRenamerProvider for adding renamers to the bulk rename dialog.

sect2.title: LunarxFileInfo
sect2.para: Lunar passes file references to the provider using LunarxFileInfo objects. The LunarxFileInfo interface provides access to the file information that Lunar has already read - mime type, URI, name, etc. Extensions should use the data from the LunarxFileInfo rather than reading it themselves, to prevent excessive I/O.

There is exactly one LunarxFileInfo per file, and it is kept around for as long as Lunar is interested in the file. Extensions can use this information to manage lifecycles of its own data - e.g. when the LunarxFileInfo goes away, it is safe for the extension to forget any private data for that file.

sect2.title: Names
sect2.para: Most objects created by the extensions need names, e.g. the LunarxMenuItems returned from the LunarxMenuProviders. These names must be namespaced with the name of the extension. For example the main item returned from the TexOpenTerminal extension (which can be found in the examples/tex-open-terminal subdirectory of the Lunar distribution) should be called TexOpenTerminal::open-terminal. The namespace must be global among the providers exported by a certain extension.

sect2.title: Types
sect2.para: Lunar extensions are loaded as GTypeModules. This means that all GTypes created by the extension must be registered with the GTypeModule, using lunarx_provider_plugin_register_type() function (or one of the convenience macros like LUNARX_DEFINE_TYPE()) rather than g_type_register_static(). All types exported by an extension must be registered in lunar_extension_initialize().

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para: Providers are LunarxProviderPlugins loaded from shared libraries installed in $libdir/lunarx-2/. The shared libraries are linked against the lunarx-2 library.
The extensions must provide three public functions, lunar_extension_initialize(), lunar_extension_shutdown() and lunar_extension_list_types().

lunar_extension_initialize() is passed a LunarxProviderPlugin object, and is responsible to register all GTypes required by the extension. lunar_extension_shutdown() should perform any extension-specific shutdown required prior to unloading the extension. lunar_extension_list_types() returns an array of GTypes that represent the types of the providers exported by the extension. Lunar will instantiate objects of those types when needed.

example.title: Basic Structure of an extension

sect1.para: You should check the TexOpenTerminal extension, which is included in the Lunar distribution in the examples/tex-open-terminal directory, for a more complete example of how to write a Lunar extension.

sect2.title: Compiling Lunar Extensions
sect2.para: To compile a Lunar extension, you need to tell the compiler where to find the lunarx header files and library. This is done with the pkg-config utility.

The following interactive shell session demonstrates how pkg-config is used (the actual output on your system will be different):
$ pkg-config --cflags lunarx-2 -DXTHREADS -DXUSE_MTSAFE_API -I/opt/local/include/lunarx-2 -I/usr/local/include/atk-1.0 \ -I/usr/local/include/glib-2.0 -I/usr/local/lib/glib-2.0/include -I/usr/X11R6/include/gtk-2.0 \ -I/usr/X11R6/lib/gtk-2.0/include -I/usr/X11R6/include -I/usr/X11R6/include/pango-1.0 \ -I/usr/local/include/freetype2 -I/usr/local/include $ pkg-config --libs lunarx-2 -Wl,--rpath -Wl,/usr/local/lib -L/usr/local/lib -L/usr/X11R6/lib -L/opt/local/lib -llunarx-2

The easiest way to compile an extension is to use the backticks feature of the shell. If you enclose a command in backticks (not single quotes), then its output will be substituted into the command line before execution. So to compile an extension, you would type the following:
$ gcc -shared -fPIC -DPIC `pkg-config --cflags --libs lunarx-2` foo.c -o foo.so

sect2.title: Installing Lunar Extensions
sect2.para:
To determine the directory where extensions must be installed on your local system, you can use the following command (as mentioned above, the output will be different on your system):
$ pkg-config --variable=extensionsdir lunarx-2 /opt/local/lib/lunarx-2

For example, to install the extension foo.so on your system, you would type the following:
$ install -d `pkg-config --variable=extensionsdir lunarx-2` $ install -c -m 0755 foo.so `pkg-config --variable=extensionsdir lunarx-2`/foo.so

sect1.title: Advanced topics
sect1.para: This section provides a short introduction to some of the advanced topics in the Lunar Extension Framework.

sect2.title: Memory-Resident Extensions
sect2.para: Some extensions may not play well with Lunar's on-demand loading and unloading of extensions. For example, an extension that uses a desktop library, which in turn registers additional static GTypes will not work after being loaded and unloaded for the first time. For these kind of extensions, Lunar provides the option to make extensions memory resident, which means the extension will be loaded once and afterwards will never be unloaded again until Lunar exits.
Such extensions must set the resident property of the provider plugin in its lunar_extension_initialize() function to TRUE, using the lunarx_provider_plugin_set_resident() method.
